block.p: U.S. Decides to Resume Talks with North Korea President Bush said the United States would resume negotiations with the reclusive Communist government on a range of issues, including North Korea's missile program and its huge deployment of soldiers on the border with South Korea.

NATO Military Gap An internal review has concluded that if the alliance's current spending plans are carried out, NATO will fulfill less than 50 percent of its ''force goals.'' NATO's secretary general, Lord Robertson, said European members were not doing enough to remedy their deficiencies and could become overly dependent on the United States in a conflict.

NATO's secretary general, Lord Robertson, said European members were not doing enough to remedy their deficiencies and could become overly dependent on the United States in a conflict.

Rumsfeld on Troops for Balkans Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said after visiting the Balkans that American troops were still needed in Kosovo to stem violence, particularly on the Macedonian border.
Macedonia threatened to declare a state of war after five government soldiers were killed in one of the deadliest attacks by ethnic Albanian rebels in weeks.

Poor Nations to Get AIDS Drug Pfizer said it would offer the governments of more than 50 poor nations an unlimited free supply of a powerful drug, which it markets under the name Diflucan, to fight fungal infections associated with AIDS.

Nepal's Royal Murder Mystery The palace said it would allow royal survivors of last week's massacre to be questioned, as wild stories surrounding the deaths of most of Nepal's royal family circulated.

Jewish Settlers Demand War Jewish settlers fought with Palestinians in the West Bank near the place where an Israeli infant was injured by Arab stone-throwing on Tuesday. Settlers later rallied in Jerusalem to demand a declaration of war against the Palestinian Authority.
Crackdown on Chinese Press Chinese authorities have removed the top editors of the country's most probing major newspaper, Southern Weekend, in a crackdown on its semi-independent reporting.

Judge Denies McVeigh Plea Seeking Stay of Execution The federal judge who presided over Timothy J. McVeigh's Oklahoma City bombing trial rejected his request to postpone his execution, which is set for Monday. The judge said that although he was shocked by the F.B.I.'s belated discovery of evidence, he did not believe that the files altered Mr. McVeigh's guilt or invalidated the death sentence. Mr. McVeigh's lawyers said they would appeal.

Senate Power Shift Is Official Democrats took control of the Senate and the new majority leader, Tom Daschle, called for ''principled compromise'' to avoid gridlock in a capital where Republicans no longer held all the levers of power. He described political polarization as ''an indulgence'' that the Senate could not afford. Negotiations between the parties continued over details of the transfer of power.
National D-Day Memorial President Bush dedicated the National D-Day Memorial in Bedford, Va., a town chosen for the memorial because it lost 21 soldiers in the landing, which took place 57 years ago.

New Air Traffic Plans The F.A.A. said that if its major programs to improve air traffic control stayed on schedule for 10 years they would raise the capacity to handle commercial flights by 30 percent but that demand would grow even faster in some areas, like New York and Chicago. Boeing later gave the first public description of its plan, which it said would supplement F.A.A. efforts and further expand capacity by using Boeing-built satellites.

New Leader for Los Angeles City Attorney James K. Hahn beat his fellow Democrat, Antonio Villaraigosa, by a margin of 54 to 46 percent in their race to succeed Richard J. Riordan, a Republican, who had backed Mr. Villaraigosa. Mr. Hahn pledged to form a ''government that looks like the city it represents.''

Smoker Awarded $3 Billion A California jury ordered Philip Morris to pay $3 billion in punitive damages to Richard Boeken, 56, a lung cancer patient who admitted to smoking at least two packs of Marlboros a day for more than 40 years.

Bloomberg Sets Out On Mayoral Campaign Trail Michael R. Bloomberg, who announced his campaign for the Republican mayoral nomination in TV ads on Tuesday, began campaigning in person with a promise to overhaul the public school system. He said he would highlight a different issue each week of the campaign.

Deal on Budget and Tax Cut Mayor Giuliani and the City Council reached agreement on a $39.6 billion budget that would trim the city's income and sales taxes while restoring money to libraries, cultural institutions and services for the elderly that the mayor had sought to cut.
Affirmation of Climate Change Top American scientists said in a report requested by the Bush White House that global warming was a real problem and getting worse.

The Heart's Partial Self-Repair Researchers reported that contrary to medical dogma some human heart muscle cells do regenerate after a heart attack, though generally too few to repair all the damage.
A Head Start on College The Board of Education is creating a program with Bard College that will let select 11th graders start college at a special institute in Brooklyn.

76ers Prevail in Overtime The Philadelphia 76ers defeated the Los Angeles Lakers 107-101 in overtime of the opening game of the National Basketball Association Finals in Los Angeles. Allen Iverson scored 48 points for Philadelphia.
U.S. Warning to Food Makers The F.D.A. warned companies putting herbal additives in food that their products could be illegal because the ''novel ingredients'' might not be widely recognized as safe.
Cendant Seeks Travel Service Cendant, which owns Avis and Days Inn, was said to be near a deal to buy Galileo International, an electronic travel reservation business, for more than $2.8 billion.
Big Fine for Toy Maker The Consumer Product Safety Commission fined the Fisher-Price division of Mattel $1.1 million for failing to report defects in toys, the largest fine ever against a toy maker.
I.R.S. Puts Business on Notice The I.R.S., faced with a small but growing tax rebellion, warned small businesses that they could be prosecuted if they refused to withhold taxes from worker paychecks.
Editorials: A restart in the Senate; the Los Angeles vote; debating Europe's future.
